Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: E-Facilitation Partnerships: Developing Scalable Online Professional Development for Expanding CS Teacher Expertise in Equity and Pedagogy with eTextiles

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of Pennsylvania, the University of Oregon, and the Education Development Center (EDC) will partner with the Exploring Computer Science (ECS) teacher community to help keep experienced high school ECS teachers engaged in the teaching profession. In the last 10 years, ECS has provided initial preparation to thousands of teachers new to teaching computer science (CS) with a focus on improving access and participation to CS for students from underserved communities. Little is known about what this new and growing population of experienced high school teachers needs to continue to grow and succeed in the teaching profession—knowledge critical for retaining and expanding CS teaching force in coming years. The project team will partner with experienced ECS facilitators and teachers to develop an online professional development program to train CS teachers in physical computing along with pedagogy skills that addresses equity into CS teaching. The newly developed, online professional develop program will then be delivered to interested ECS teachers over the course of two years. Outcomes from this work will be analyzed and case studies capturing teacher and facilitator experiences will be developed.

This collaborative project between The University of Pennsylvania, The University of Oregon, and The Education Development Center (EDC) seeks to engage the Exploring Computer Science (ECS) teacher community to determine what experienced high school ECS teachers need to continue to grow and stay engaged in the teaching profession. The PIs propose to partner with a core group of experienced ECS teachers to develop a fully online and time efficient PD model that can handle the challenges of preparing teachers in physical computing while providing a supportive context for discussing equity issues. They will leverage the newly released ECS curriculum unit on electronic textiles (e-textiles), which situates computational thinking within designing functional circuitry in hands-on, personalized crafts, to develop ECS PD. The project team is versed in addressing issues of equity and diversity in CS, and it brings together expertise in teacher learning, computer science education, online instructional design, and learning sciences. This RPP addresses the critical goals for CS education: (1) identify needs of experienced ECS teachers for continued learning and engagement with CS; (2) create and pilot online PD and facilitation for physical computing with e-textiles; (3) examine how online facilitation can expand ECS teachers’ pedagogical capacities for addressing in equitable ways students’ CS interests and perspectives; (4) build and scale facilitator capacities within the ECS community; and (5) contribute to knowledge on how professional teacher communities can support CS pedagogical practices.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant supported the development of online professional development facilitators for introducing high school teachers to the electronic textiles (“e-textiles”) curricular resources (http://www.exploringcs.org/e-textiles) to use in the Exploring Computer Science program. Over the course of four years, we offered online summer professional development workshops and quarterly professional development sessions to a total of 25 teachers in 25 schools across 9 states—California, Alabama, Mississippi, Illinois (Chicago), Wisconsin, Oregon, Delaware, Massachusetts (Boston), Virginia—in metropolitan centers, suburbs, and rural areas. A total of 17 teachers implemented the unit in 69 classes, reaching a total of 1,403 students. 

Using a cascading mentoring model, these summer and quarterly professional development sessions provided opportunities for two cohorts of ECS teachers to experience e-textiles in nine days of (all virtual) professional development (five days in summer and four days of quarterly meetings), implement the e-textiles unit in one or more computer science classes, then follow-up with a second round of professional development and further e-textiles implementation. Further, all eight teachers from the first cohort of professional development helped lead professional development for the second cohort. From the second cohort, three additional teachers additionally began leading professional development in workshops organized beyond the grant, in the state of Oregon.  We also conducted pre- and post-interviews with teachers to understand their particular needs, the context of teaching computer science in their school, district, and state, and the role of e-textiles in meeting their professional and classroom needs. In addition, we interviewed each facilitator about the process of learning to facilitate e-textiles professional development. In addition to the development of e-textiles facilitators, we created a full nine-day virtual professional development model, adding videos and updating the curriculum materials with new technology platforms to make it possible for teachers to use without needing access to additional software.

Our project team also conducted extensive research on experienced computer science teacher professional needs and development. We discovered that experienced CS teachers move and advocate for education outside of their classroom walls, recruiting students to their classrooms, connecting with parents, community, and approaching administrators for resources. Four of the teachers in our grant presented at educator-focused computer science conferences (e.g., local CSTA branches). Further, several teacher-led workshops took place in MA, CA, IL, OR and virtual locations (due to COVID during our grant period), introducing additional local teacher communities to e-textiles. Finally, we published our research findings in one journal publication, four conference proceedings, and presented at academic and professional conference venues.
